Hey @Aviral Srivastava , several people seem to be facing this issue right now. We are discussing it in the topic "error in running server" at the moment :)

You have changes on top of master, run this:

$ git add .
$ git stash
$ git fetch upstream && git rebase upstream/master
$ git stash pop

then do pip install

where packages are all the python modules that you need

So in this case, run pip install --no-deps --requirement /root/zulip/requirements/py2_prod.txt, since that is the command pip has trouble with.

Could not open requirements file: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/root/zulip/requirements/py2_prod.txt'

Aka the one for prod. Should be pip install --no-deps --requirement /srv/zulip/requirements/py2_dev.txt

gtg to lunch, but it seems like what went wrong is a new enough version of pip isn't installed, and so it can't handle the fact that we apparently include -r common.txt in two places in the chain of dependencies below py2_dev.txt

A little update on this: @Divyanshu Agarwal continued to fix the pip error in the private chat and now got it to be updated to 9.0.1
yes pip 9.0.1
now should I run the above commands, that we running before pip upgradation

@Tim Abbott The issue is probably to be found in two different ways of installing pip:

  • via pip install pip
  • via apt-get pip

Those two methods stored pip at different locations:

  • /usr/local/bin/pip
  • /usr/bin/pip

So all of our efforts to update pip actually did update pip, but /usr/local/bin/pip, where as the system searched pip in /urs/bin/pip (which pip).

The issue got resolved by running hash -r, which cleaned the cache of the bash and thus the wrong path that prevailed after updating.
@Divyanshu Agarwal yes, run the previous commands

$ exit
$ vagrant halt
$ vagrant destroy
$ vagrant up  // gonna take you some time here
$ vagrant ssh
Is I have to run all these commands again
You should, it's cleaner.
okay
@Steve Howell I saw that you opened a new issue for common vagrant issues, so this might be one solution for the 'pip is outdated' one.
I still don't really feel I understand the issue -- you shouldn't need to run hash -r to have /usr/local/bin take precendence over /usr/bin
And in theory, we were starting from a stock Ubuntu machine

Finally , issue resolved, and now I'm in zulip environment.
main error was due to old version of pip, which was upgraded by running some commands, as discussed with Robert.
Thanks everyone for help..
That's great news, @Divyanshu Agarwal :)
